title: 114_hr4042
content: The Act may be cited as the "Pre-K for USA Act." Congress finds that the United States ranks 25th in early learning enrollment, with studies showing that access to high-quality prekindergarten programs leads to academic success and reduces the likelihood of negative outcomes such as grade repetition, drug problems, and incarceration. Additionally, every public dollar spent on prekindergarten programs yields a $7 return through reduced spending on other services. Despite these benefits, about 40 percent of school districts do not offer prekindergarten programs. Children who attend prekindergarten have higher GPAs, are more likely to attend college, and have lower arrest rates. However, 40% of school districts do not offer prekindergarten programs, and over half of those that do only offer part-day programs. Texas missed out on millions in federal funding for prekindergarten programs due to education budget cuts. Some local governments funded full-day prekindergarten programs in response to these cuts, highlighting the need for direct federal funding for prekindergarten programs. SEC. 3. PREKINDERGARTEN DEVELOPMENT GRANTS. The Secretary of Education, in consultation with the Secretary of Health and Human Services, will award competitive grants to increase capacity for high-quality prekindergarten programs. Grants will be awarded for up to 3 years and applications must be submitted by Governors or chief executive officers of eligible entities. States must consult with the State Advisory Council on Early Childhood Education and Care when developing their grant applications. To be eligible for a grant under this Act, a State or local government entity must contribute non-Federal matching funds equal to at least 20% of the grant amount. These funds can come from State funding, local funding, philanthropy, or in-kind contributions. In order to receive a grant under this Act, a State or local government entity must provide non-Federal matching funds, which can be in the form of State funding, local funding, philanthropy, or in-kind contributions. The Secretary may waive or reduce the matching funds requirement for entities facing extreme financial hardship. Grant recipients can also award subgrants to eligible entities using the grant funds. The Secretary may waive or reduce the matching funds requirement for entities facing extreme financial hardship. Grant recipients can award subgrants to eligible entities using the grant funds. The Secretary may not award a subgrant if the State, agency, or entity received funding for the program in the same fiscal year. Authorization of appropriations is set at $750,000,000 for fiscal year 2016 and necessary sums for fiscal years 2017 through 2025. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "eligible local entity" refers to a local educational agency, early childhood education program provider, or a consortium of such entities. The term "full-day" means a day equivalent to a full school day in the State and not less than 5 hours. The term "high-quality prekindergarten program" is a program supported by an eligible local entity. The term "high-quality prekindergarten program" refers to a program supported by an eligible local entity that serves children aged 3 or 4, or those who have attained the legal age for State-funded prekindergarten. It requires high staff qualifications, including teachers with a bachelor's degree in early childhood education or a related field. The high-quality prekindergarten program funded by an eligible local entity serves children aged 3 or 4, or those eligible for State-funded prekindergarten. It requires teachers to have a bachelor's degree in early childhood education or a related field, or demonstrate knowledge through a State-approved assessment and engage in ongoing professional development for at least 2 years. The prekindergarten program funded by an eligible local entity requires teachers to have a bachelor's degree in early childhood education or a related field, engage in ongoing professional development for at least 2 years, and maintain a maximum class size of 20 children with a child to instructional staff ratio not exceeding 10 to 1. The prekindergarten program funded by an eligible local entity requires teachers to have a bachelor's degree in early childhood education or a related field, engage in ongoing professional development for at least 2 years, maintain a maximum class size of 20 children, a child to instructional staff ratio not exceeding 10 to 1, offer a full-day program, provide developmentally appropriate learning environments and evidence-based curricula aligned with State standards, offer competitive salaries, conduct ongoing monitoring and program evaluation, and provide comprehensive services including health screenings. The prekindergarten program funded by an eligible local entity requires teachers to have a bachelor's degree in early childhood education or a related field, engage in ongoing professional development, maintain small class sizes, offer full-day programs with developmentally appropriate environments, and provide comprehensive services including health screenings, family engagement opportunities, and nutrition services. The prekindergarten program funded by an eligible local entity includes services such as parent education, family literacy, nutrition services aligned with guidelines, programs for children with disabilities, and physical activity programs. The prekindergarten program funded by an eligible local entity includes services such as parent education, family literacy, nutrition services, programs for children with disabilities, physical activity programs, and high-quality professional development for staff. The prekindergarten program funded by an eligible local entity includes high-quality professional development for staff, in-class observation for teachers, meeting education performance standards, and maintaining health and safety standards.
